Introduction to scAtlas#

Why atlas#

One of the most exciting technological innovations in recent years is the rapid development of single-cell technologies, which allow us to examine cells at a remarkable level of detail [Lotfollahi et al., 2024]. As a result, numerous well-curated reference atlases have emerged, providing valuable resources for researchers—such as the lung atlas [Lake et al., 2023], kidney atlas [Sikkema et al., 2023], and the bone atlas [Han et al., 2024]. But why do we still need these atlases? Here are a few reasons:

  • Atlases provide high-resolution annotations that can be transferred to individual studies through reference-mapping algorithms. [Lotfollahi et al., 2024]

  • They enable comparative analyses between different conditions, such as healthy versus diseased states, yielding valuable biological insights. [Sikkema et al., 2023]

  • Atlases offer a unified framework for trajectory analysis and gene module discovery, facilitating a deeper understanding of cellular dynamics.[Han et al., 2024]
